content:
I'm looking forward to receiving the pictures of the sextant!

Regarding your rare 1980s vinyl record, that's a great idea to get it appraised! There are several reputable music appraisers and collectors you can reach out to. Here are a few options:

1. **Discogs**: Discogs is a comprehensive online database of music releases, and they have a community of collectors and sellers who can help you determine the value of your vinyl record. You can create a listing for your record and ask for feedback from the community.
2. **Vinyl Me, Please**: Vinyl Me, Please is a popular online vinyl subscription service that also offers appraisal services. They have a team of experts who can help you determine the value of your record.
3. **The Vinyl Factory**: The Vinyl Factory is a UK-based company that offers vinyl manufacturing, appraisal, and valuation services. They have a team of experts who can help you determine the value of your record.
4. **MusicStack**: MusicStack is an online marketplace for buying and selling new and used vinyl records. They have a team of experts who can help you determine the value of your record.
5. **Local Record Stores**: Reach out to local record stores in your area that specialize in vintage or rare vinyl records. They often have knowledgeable staff who can appraise your record and provide guidance on its value.

When reaching out to these services, be sure to provide high-quality photos of your record, including the cover art, labels, and any inserts or sleeves. Additionally, provide any information you have about the record's condition, rarity, and provenance.

Remember to research each service's fees and terms before committing to an appraisal. Some services may charge a fee for the appraisal, while others may offer free appraisals but take a commission if you decide to sell the record through them.

Good luck, and I hope you get a great appraisal for your rare vinyl record!

(And don't forget to send those sextant pictures whenever you're ready!)
